thread.title: Centennial buys up entire Rushcutters Bay apartment block
thread.title_full: Centennial buys up entire Rushcutters Bay apartment block | afr.com

author: Mercedes Ruehl
title: Centennial buys up entire Rushcutters Bay apartment block
text:
Rushcutters Bay block of apartments sells for $10.5m Supplied. by Mercedes Ruehl Fund manager Centennial Property Group has paid $10.5 million for a block of units the inner-Sydney suburb of Rushcutters Bay, one of many existing apartment complexes to sell in one-line in the last couple of months.
Eight buyers fought it out for the single-titled building at 50-54 Bayswater Road , which neighbours the high-profile suburb of Kings Cross. The strip, once known for its glittering nightclub scene has seen a wave of residential development after strict new licensing laws were introduced by the state government several years ago.
Centennial Property Group a low-profile Sydney-based group, saw the property as an attractive investment, especially given the predicted jump in population growth in the area.
The sale was managed by CBRE's Nicholas Heaton and Xavier Rahmeâ€‹ on behalf of a private investor, The Bayswater Road property, which was sold to Centennial post-auction includes three shops and 27 studio apartments and will show an initial yield of about 5.5 per cent.
"The changing demographic in King Cross and surrounding areas due to the lock-out laws has resulted in more buyers actively looking to invest in the area," Mr Heaton said.
Premium possible for blocks "This is the fourth block of apartments we have sold in as many months with more in the pipeline. Traditionally sold down individually, vendors are choosing to sell apartment blocks in one line and are now achieving retail prices, if not a premium."
Centennial could also strata-title the block and sell the units individually at some time in the future.
 Earlier this month Ramsay Property Group bought an apartment building in Annandale, with 74 units, for $37 million through CBRE.
The results are prompting more owners to sell. Mr Heaton said CBRE is now marketing a block of eight apartments in Campsie and 10 apartments in Petersham that are drawing similar interest from buyers wanting to be a part of Sydney's rental and capital growth story.
Centennial tends to look for assets with value-add opportunity. Last year it bought the North Sydney office building, 132 Arthur Street, from Valad Property Group for $37 million.
